values:
This story makes it official: Stephen King has run out of ideas.

I mean, honestly...cell phones? When I think of electronic appliances, the cell phone is one of the least terrifying I can imagine (VCRs, though, are a different story). This is like if the crotchety old man who lives down the street from me wrote a book about people who walk on his grass being swallowed alive by the lawn. I will give him credit for trying to make zombies a part of the story though; whenever in doubt, just go with zombies.

IN OTHER NEWS:
Speaking of trying to portray mundane things as vehicles for terror, I give you The Lift. That might just be my favorite movie poster of all time.

This post is for Ian, who I talked to a few nights ago about what I referred to as "the untitled Will Ferrell NASCAR comedy." It turns out you were right, and the permanent title is Talledega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby. The title is eerily similar to Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy, but in a good way.

Sorry for the lame subject title, but I'm really bad at coming up with my own Gene Shalit puns. But that's not what this post is about; no, this post is about the way Shalit has become a punching bag for GLAAD because of his negative review of Brokeback Mountain. Unfortunately, because I haven't seen the movie yet I don't want to completely pass judgement one way or the other on the issue. I will say this, though: this seems like a misguided attempt at outrage by GLAAD. Is it really possible to take offense at one of Gene Shalit's reviews? Does this look like a bigot to you?



I mean, honestly, how many people are going to be driven toward homophobia by the musings of Gene Shalit? Actually, for a while there I thought Gene Shalit was gay, until I found out that he was married and had two kids. My point here is this: leave the man alone. Let him pun in peace. Wait...I feel a pun coming on! Here it goes: Those people are mad at Shalit should talk to him and try being friends with him...they'll be GLAAD they did!

You're right, that sucked.

Since I'm the only person I know who was both in a marching band in high school and has an unhealthy love of all things zombie, this idea will probably appeal to nobody but me, but I'll still repeat it here: I'd love to see a marching band do a Dawn of the Dead halftime show, where over the course of the 10-minute show the entire band gets eaten. For good measure, I'd also have to throw in some firearms. I honestly think I'm onto something here. IN OTHER NEWS: Last night on The Daily Show, Jon Stewart referred to Dick Cheney as "He Who Walks Behind the Rows"...that is Peabody-winning humor right there.
Tonight marks the return of Insomniac Cinema from a two-week hiatus, and the movie being screened will be Snatch. So, who's still here in TO, and who's up for a movie tonight?

As an added bonus to my anti-USC post last night, here's a quote from ESPN.com's Bill Simmons from his Running Diary of the game last night:

"In his postgame interview, Matt Leinart throws out a classic, 'I think we're a better football team, they just made the plays in the end,' backhanded compliment. You're right, we shouldn't have played the game, Matt. That was stupid. You guys were better."

The news just came through today that noted character actor (and That Guy Hall of Fame nominee) Patrick Crenshaw has passed away. Crenshaw was best known as a go-to guy whenever the role of "Old Man" needed to be filled. He played that part so well, in fact, that he was able to play the role of "Old Man" as far back as 1970, on Green Acres (he actually played two roles on that show: "Grandpa" first and then "Old Man" later). He later played an old mail sorter in The Hudsucker Proxy (my favorite film) and the old man married to Jennifer Coolidge in Best in Show. He reached the pinnacle of his career with his performance as "Blue" in Old School, where he was a crucial part of one of the funniest funeral scenes committed to film (though most of the credit rightly sits with Will Ferrell) but never stopped to slow down, appearing in 6 films in the 3 years before he died.

The man was a legend in my book, an instantly recognizable face and a shoe-in for the That Guy Hall of Fame. I'll never forget Patrick Crenshaw, or the way he was able to play his role so well. Should someone ask me how he died, I'll lift my head up high and in a proud, steady voice say that he died from being an Old Man.

If everything goes according to plan, I'll be out of TO by August, living in New Hampshire, Kansas or North Carolina. I assume that when I move to one of these places, I'll be asked questions about what its like to live in Southern California. I think this story (which occurred Wednesday night) will be good one to use:

I was having dinner with my family at The Smoke House, a restaurant located across the street from the old Warner Brothers studio lot that was once a hot-spot for people in show business. It's like a low-rent version of Musso & Franks, but with better prime rib. Since its glory days as the only place for real celebrities to dine, its reputation has fallen quite a bit. Where once there was a strict dress code, now there was only sad-looking parties in t-shirts and shorts; the decor, which I'm sure at one point was top-notch, would today be deemed too tacky by today's hollywood elite. 

Seeing this when I walked in didn't phase me, because I knew the former reputation of The Smoke House, but had no expectations other than a good meal I wouldn't have to pay for. When my younger sisters asked me if we would see any celebrities, I confidently answered "No."

But I was wrong.

Oh yes, I was wrong. For halfway through the meal, I saw Him. Sitting with three friends, debating whose turn it was to pay the bill. He was instantly recognizeable, a face so deeply etched in my memory I felt like I was staring into the face of an old friend. I knew almost his entire body of work, had watched his performances with nothing short of awe and admiration. And here he was, sitting 15 feet away from me...it was Him.

Scott Bakula.

Scott. Bakula. Dr. Sam Beckett from Quantum fucking Leap. You think living in Southern California doesn't get you brushes with greatness? Glimpses of celebrities? The witnessing of raw star power in action? Well think again; I saw all three on display, on one Wednesday night at The Smoke House.

And that's a true story.

I just got back from taking the GRE, which thanks to it being computer-based saved me the two weeks of anxiety just so I could go directly to the next few months of feeling incompetant.

Here's the damage:
VERBAL - 550
QUANTITATIVE - 440

I'll hear back on the analytical writing in 10 days, but until then its back to my grad school applications. Woo.

Monday: Spanish I, 10:00-11:50 Tuesday: OFF Wednesday: Spanish I, 10:00-11:50 History of Nazi Germany, 1:00-3:50 Thursday: OFF Friday: OFF Now tell me that's not the prettiest looking schedule you've ever seen. I love you, schedule.

I'm thankful for only one thing, really: Best Buy. And I'll tell you why...Arrested Development Season 1, $14.99...Arrested Development Season 2, $14.99.

IN OTHER NEWS:
Now that I'm 21 and have no problem drinking, I've found that a single White Russian can go a long way when I'm spending an extended period of time with my relatives. Like, say, at a Thanksgiving dinner.

I don't quite say it often enough, but Thomas Jefferson truly is one of my favorite historical figures, almost a historical role model. Here's just one reason I love Thomas Jefferson so much, from "Jesus Without the Miracles," an article in this month's Harper's Magazine:

"It would indeed by a positive step if Christians actually began to follow the teachings of the founder. Something similar was no doubt on the mind of another Virginian, Thomas Jefferson, when he took a pair of scissors to the King James Bible two hundred years ago. Jefferson cut out the virgin birth, all the miracles--including the most important one, the Resurrection--then pasted together what was left and called it The Philosophy of Jesus of Nazareth."

Only a man as accomplished as Thomas Jefferson would have the balls to actually edit the Bible...and might I add, he probably did a damn fine job of it.

You know, when it comes right down to it, I don't think there's any word funnier than "hobo."

That being said, here is a list of 700 Hobo Names, written and recited by John Hodgman, author of The Areas of My Expertise--which is not yet available at my local Borders or Barnes & Noble. If you have an hour to kill it's worth a listen...though you get the jist of it pretty quickly.

Marcus Chickenstock...Utah Manfred Suckermunt...Edwin Winnepeg...Eyepatch Reese Hand-iron...Cricket-Eating Charles Diggs...Hally McAffable, Everybody's Friend...Lil' Shorty Longhorn...Swing-State Myron...Sweetback Barney, the Diletante...Blind Buck and Woozy, the Invisible Seeing Eye Dog...Fake Cockney Accent Allen Strip...

EDIT: After finally listening to the entire 53+ minute recording I am less impressed by the fact that John Hodgman could write 700 Hobo Names, but still awed by the sheer genius of it. Listening to it, I think I broke Hodgman's "code" for a good hobo name: ADJECTIVE/NOUN-REGULAR FIRST NAME-TWO WORD LAST NAME, the NOUN-VERB <--(optional). Using the code, it's possible to write 10,000 Hobo Names. Here's an example I made myself: Slick Amos Muffinwater, the Chicken Catcher.

Listen to John Hodgman's recording, follow the formula and go have some fun. You can even give yourself a hobo name (I'm Bum-Leg Jack Shebang)

Since the American version of The Office came out I've been marveling over the ways in which it has forged its own independent identity from that of its British counterpart, to the point that I felt compelled to break out my old Office DVDs and remember what was so classic about Ricky Gervais' version. There's one part that I had forgotten about completely, when David Brent reads a poem he had written when he was in his early twenties, which I will reproduce here: "Excalibur" I froze your tears and made a dagger and stabbed it in my cock forever. It stays there like Excalibur Are your my Arthur? Say you are. Take this cool, dark steeled blade, steal it, sheath it in your lake. I'd drown with you to be together. Must you breathe? 'Cause I need Heaven.

Showing tonight at Insomniac Cinema:



"I think the problem may have been, that there was a Stonehenge monument on the stage, that was in danger of being crushed...by a dwarf."

The Shat says that this will be "the ultimate piece of Star Trek memorabilia" and I'll be damned if he ain't right.

IN OTHER NEWS:
Fuck! I missed the first episode of The Comedians of Comedy. And I couldn't go to the film screening at The Egyptian. Goddamn, I was totally psyched for this then completely forgot.

Another great episode...I'm beginning to get antsy for a second season DVD.

Great line from tonight:
"And finally I'd like to quote Lex Luthor, 'Dad, you have no idea what I am capable of."
"Is that from Superman?"
"...Smallville."

List five songs that you currently love. It doesn't matter what genre they are from, whether they have words, or even if they're any good, but they must be songs you're really enjoying right now. Post these instructions, the artists, and the songs in your blog. Then tag five other Livejournal friends to see what they're listening to.

1) Ever Fallen in Love? - The Buzzcocks
2) Title and Registration - Death Cab for Cutie
3) Queen Bitch - David Bowie
4) Jenny Was A Friend of Mine - The Killers
5) Prepare for the Fight - The Lovemakers

Keep 'em coming, Yorde.

IN OTHER NEWS:
Recently I've been feeling a lot like I'm all dressed up with no place to go, having hipped up my wardrobe and changed my appearance considerably. There are nights when I wish I had a place to be but I realize that I don't have anywhere to go and nobody to go there with. Every day I spend living in TO feels like an extra day of a prison sentence.

Screw you, .

IN OTHER NEWS:
I have to go to Valencia and play soldier this weekend, which means that I'm going to miss an Insomniac Cinema show that I have been anticipating for a very long time: P.T. Anderson's Magnolia. Under normal circumstances, Magnolia would at best be considered a "good movie" by me, save for the otherworldly performance given by Tom Cruise as Frank "TJ" Mackey, who I can only describe as a speaker who is a mixture of Tony Robbins and Tom Leykis. It's Cruise who makes the entire film by perfectly delivering his character's catch phrase: "Respect...the COCK!", which will always make my list of favorite movie quotes (another one, "You are gonna give me that cherry pie sweet mama baby", receives honorable mention). Plus, Patton Oswalt has a cameo...I'm definitely sad to be missing one.

But--oh my God--This Is Spinal Tap is next week. I can only hope they play it in Dobly.

Ever since I finally stopped being overweight, I have had an underlying fear that I'll gain back most of the weight without there being sufficient photographic evidence that I was thin at one time. With that said, here's physical proof of my claims that I'm 160 pounds:



This is just in case I fall off the wagon and go on a month-long In-N-Out bender.
Why? Because puppies are cute, that's why.

...I think I'd by very good at coming up with entertaining double-bills, such as what I watched in my home theater (my room) tonight: Casablanca, followed by Children of the Corn.
IN OTHER NEWS: I would find the regular dictionary much more entertaining if it assumed the laid-back attitude of urbandictionary.com; an example: Hollaback Girl - "A term that Gwen Stefani apparently just made the fuck up and tries to pass on as regular slang."
I am consistently amazed and bewildered by my ability to ruin potential relationships.

Hey , have you heard anything about the new Bob Spitz biography of The Beatles that makes it worth buying?...the moment I heard "900+ page biography on The Beatles" I figured it would be a must-buy, but now I'm seeing a bit of talk about the many factual errors in the book. I think I may have been duped by an extensive marketing campaign for a crappy book. Oh well.

An interesting fact worth pointing out that I realized after watching last night's episode: Steve Carell's version of The Office has now run for as many episodes (12) as the original Ricky Gervais version. So far this version has shown that it can be funny in its own way and the characters have established that they are not caricatures of the British version, but are uniquely funny.

However...has it attained the same "classic" status that the British "Office" did? The answer for me is "not yet." But let's be honest: how can you expect a television show to build itself into a comic masterpiece after 12 episodes? It's amazing that Gervais' Office was able to do so.

But don't get me wrong: I love this new version of The Office. It's become the highlight of my week and I've slowly turned into That Guy who tells people constantly to watch The Office. Personally, I think this new version is getting very close to eclipsing the British version, but it has yet to succeed in putting out one classic scene that helps define the series itself. The scenes I have in mind here are David Brent playing "Freelove Freeway" on Series 1 and the "David Brent Dance" from Series 2:



So far, the closest the new version has come has been "the Chris Rock Routine" from the first season and last night's episode when Dwight and Michael decide to have a fight in Dwight's dojo to see who could take who. Both are great scenes, but in the end are too short to stand up among the Ricky Gervais classics.

Not to worry, though. The Office has been ordered for 13 episodes this season, with a possible extension to 22, so there's still a lot of comedy yet to watch.

You piss off everybody but other pretentious indie assholes. You suck extremely hard and only listen to stuff on pitchfork media. Fuck you."

I didn't really feel the need to buy the Land of the Dead DVD when it was released, but I did rent it today, and felt like recommending renting it in order to see the video diary of Shaun of the Dead's Simon Pegg and his trip to the set of the movie. The best part (which is much MUCH funnier when you actually watch it) is this line, which Pegg delivers like a British host of a So You Want To Be A Zombie infomercial:
"Hello, I'm a zombie. Now, as you can see, I'm infirmed by necrosis...but it's not all that bad, and after a while you do get used to it. So if you'd like to be a zombie, please come to my trailer and I'll bite you in the face."
